## News Review for canon

# Canon Technology News Review

## Executive Summary

Canon has enhanced its professional camera lineup with advanced stacked sensor technology in the flagship EOS R1 and EOS R5 Mark II models, achieving readout speeds of 2.7-2.8 milliseconds and 6 milliseconds respectively, which reduces rolling shutter artifacts by 85-95% compared to conventional sensors ([Fstoppers](https://fstoppers.com/gear/rolling-shutter-why-your-golf-club-looks-bent-photos-717704)). This technical advancement positions Canon competitively in the professional sports and action photography markets by delivering performance that matches or exceeds Nikon's Z8/Z9 cameras while avoiding the dynamic range penalties and higher costs associated with Sony's global shutter approach in the a9 III, demonstrating Canon's strategic choice to prioritize image quality and affordability over cutting-edge sensor technology.

## Key Developments

**Product Enhancements:**
- Canon EOS R1 flagship camera features stacked CMOS sensor architecture with memory layered directly behind photodiodes, achieving 2.7-2.8 millisecond readout speeds for professional sports photography applications ([Fstoppers](https://fstoppers.com/gear/rolling-shutter-why-your-golf-club-looks-bent-photos-717704))
- Canon EOS R5 Mark II incorporates stacked sensor design that balances high resolution capabilities with 6 millisecond readout speed, providing professional-level rolling shutter suppression ([Fstoppers](https://fstoppers.com/gear/rolling-shutter-why-your-golf-club-looks-bent-photos-717704))

**Market Positioning:**
- Canon positions its flagship cameras as professional tools using stacked sensor technology rather than adopting global shutter solutions, targeting 95-98% of professional use cases while maintaining cost effectiveness ([Fstoppers](https://fstoppers.com/gear/rolling-shutter-why-your-golf-club-looks-bent-photos-717704))

## Market Context

Canon's implementation of stacked sensor technology aligns with broader industry trends where professional camera manufacturers are adopting this approach over global shutter solutions due to cost and image quality considerations ([Fstoppers](https://fstoppers.com/gear/rolling-shutter-why-your-golf-club-looks-bent-photos-717704)). The company competes directly with Nikon's Z8/Z9 stacked sensor cameras while differentiating from Sony's global shutter approach in the a9 III, with professional photographers accepting the stacked sensor solution as sufficient for most applications without the trade-offs associated with global shutter technology.

## Strategic Implications

Canon's technical specifications demonstrate a strategic focus on delivering professional-grade performance while maintaining competitive pricing and image quality standards. The EOS R1's faster readout speeds compared to Nikon's comparable models, combined with better low-light performance than Sony's global shutter alternative, positions Canon to capture market share in professional sports and action photography segments. This approach suggests Canon prioritizes practical performance improvements that serve the majority of professional use cases rather than pursuing cutting-edge technology that may compromise other camera attributes or increase costs significantly.

### Article 2: Rolling Shutter: Why Your Golf Club Looks Bent in Photos

**Source:** [View Full Article](https://fstoppers.com/gear/rolling-shutter-why-your-golf-club-looks-bent-photos-717704)

## Summary

Canon's flagship EOS R1 and high-resolution R5 Mark II cameras feature stacked sensor technology that delivers readout speeds of 2.7-2.8ms and 6ms respectively, reducing rolling shutter artifacts by 85-95% compared to conventional sensors. This positions Canon competitively against Nikon's Z8/Z9 cameras while avoiding the dynamic range penalties and higher costs associated with Sony's global shutter approach in the a9 III, with Canon concluding that stacked sensors provide sufficient rolling shutter suppression for most professional applications without compromising image quality or affordability.
